history.content:
Is the professor teaching any courses this semester that you could drop in on?

If not, it's also possible that they're on leave, or maybe they're just ignoring all of these emails until the adjustment period / after graduate students have had a chance to enroll.

But if you can't make any contact with the professor (either online or in person), then you're basically out of luck.

children.subject: You could try dropping in at the end of class, sure.
OP here, the professor is teaching one class that meets once a week on fridays would it be appropiate for me to just drop in? at the beginning or at the end of the class?

history.content: You might want to drop in to the professor's office hours. Right now almost all faculty are at the retreat; try office hours next week.

children.subject: Depending on the class, the professor may want to wait and see how many grad students wind up in class at the beginning of the semester, so your idea of sitting in on the class during the first week in fall may be a good one if you don't track him or her down now.

history.content: I am trying to take a graduate class taught at the school of information. I've emailed the professor three times with a five days interval between emails. The emails were essentially the same and hopefully would just be a reminder for the professor to reply back. In the email I asked whether I could take the class and why I think I can succeed in the class/I am qualified. The professor hasn't replied back and I already had my phase 1. I really want to take the class and can't find the professor's office hours online. I can't enroll in the class either since I would need a special code for enrolling. Any advice on what should I do? I could maybe try attending the first classes next semester (since the schedule is on calcentral) and try to convince the professor to let me into the class...
history.subject: I want to take a graduate class but professor won't reply
